results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 - Red
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 Red was broadcast as the first of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Space Between the Gaps (Paul Gafney), abcTVxyz (Dale Nason), The Visitor (Andrew Till) and Third Eye (Ollie Olsen).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 Red is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Australia's anti-war movement: 1965-1972
results.brief_description: The initially small minority protesting against Australian involvement in the Vietnam War flourished into a massive mobilisation against the war that not only ended Australian participation in the war, but also radicalised and irreversibly changed Australian society. In this video three participants in the anti-war movement discuss their involvement. Irene Miller was an original member of the Save Our Sons Movement, one of the earliest of the anti-war organisations. Michael Hamel-Green was a draft resister and he gives a fascinating account of the “underground” movement which worked to protect draft resisters from prison by installing them in “safe houses”. Jean McLean discusses the history of the anti-war movement and the lead up to the first anti-war Moratorium in 1970, the largest protest in Australia’s history.

results.title: Bare
results.creator_credit: Amanda Roberts, Wild Iris Productions, Liz Baulch and Deborah Strutt
results.brief_description: There are misunderstandings aplenty in this award-winning Australian short when 2 gay boys accidentally catch their lesbian neighbours in an early morning clinch. High density living in all its revealing glory.

results.title: The Trout harvest
results.creator_credit: Ted Davis, Victoria. Dept. of Fisheries and Wildlife and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: The Snobs Creek fish hatchery was newly established at this time, and this film shows how the fish are bred from the egg stage to liberation into rivers and lakes. This film was included in the San Francisco Film Festival 1961.

results.title: Kombi Karma
results.brief_description: Kombi Karma examines a cultural icon through the eyes of a diverse group of VW Kombi van lovers. Rachael travels the Victorian countryside in her Kombi and describes her camping trips as ‘more comfortable than being at home’. David, a Kombi enthusiast for over 30 years, is fascinated by the van’s early beginnings as an economical utilities vehicle in occupied Germany during World War II. Some tell of their love of the Kombi’s idiosyncratic design, ‘I love the box shape because it’s such a practical thing to put things in’. Andrew lovingly restores Kombis and believes ‘once you’re bitten by it, it never really goes away, once you own one you really wouldn’t want to own any other sort of car’. And Jan has learned to love Kombis again after her former partner smashed her newly restored Kombi to pieces with a wood splitter. But perhaps Ben sums it up best when he explains that being a Kombi devotee means that ‘you are someone who enjoys the journey as much as the destination’.

results.title: Protest projection on Twitter HQ
results.brief_description: On November 18, self-described ‘projection activist’ Alan Marling used a neighboring building to project messages of protest and disdain towards Elon Musk, on to the facade of Twitter HQ in San Francsisco. Phrases such as, “Musk’s Hellscape” and “Worthless billionare’ were projected in large white text across the building for over an hour to call in to question Musk’s ethics, investments and further highlight the current conditions of his employees at Twitter since he toko over the company in October. Marling began protesting outside Twitter HQ back in 2017 to stand against Donald Trump’s presidency and use of Twitter as public platform.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Lawless oligarch. Worthless billionaire. Space Karen. These are just some of the labels activist Alan Marling projected onto Twitter’s San Francisco HQ to describe new owner Elon Musk. The scrolling text questioned Musk’s ethics, investments and treatment of employees after taking over the company in October. On Twitter itself, the vibe was apocalyptic, with many users lamenting the end (using the hashtag #RIPTwitter) and Musk’s unbanning of controversial figures like Donald Trump. This real-world projection protest reflects the kinds of commentary users are making about the site’s new overlord.
description_for_label: Lawless oligarch. Worthless billionaire. Space Karen. These are just some of the labels activist Alan Marling projected onto Twitter’s San Francisco HQ to describe new owner Elon Musk. The scrolling text questioned Musk’s ethics, investments and treatment of employees after taking over the company in October. On Twitter itself, the vibe was apocalyptic, with many users lamenting the end and Musk’s unbanning of controversial figures like Donald Trump. This real-world projection protest reflects the kinds of commentary users are making on the site about its new overlord.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Happy Transgender Awareness Week
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @alexpepsii's Tiktok post
results.brief_description:
Transgender Awareness Week aims to raise the visibility of transgender people and address issues faced by the community. Social media plays an important role, with users sharing their own stories and amplifying the voices of transgender people. This video celebrates Transgender Awareness Week through a compilation of transgender characters in recent film and television, from Raúl in Wendell & Wild to Natalie in Big Mouth.
Transgender Awareness Week is a one-week celebration held annually from 13 - 19 November. It leads up to Transgender Day of Remembrance on 20 November which memorialises the victims of transphobic violence.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Transgender Awareness Week raises the visibility of transgender people and address issues faced by the community. Social media plays a vital role, with users sharing their stories and amplifying the voices of transgender people. This video celebrates Transgender Awareness Week through a compilation of transgender characters in recent film and television, from Raúl in Wendell & Wild to Natalie in Big Mouth. Transgender Awareness Week is held from 13 to 19 November, and leads to Transgender Day of Remembrance, which memorialises victims of transphobic violence.

results.title: run 5: the journal of Strategic Studies Group [games magazine] Issue 25, 1996
results.creator_credit: Strategic Studies Group and Stephen Hand
results.brief_description:
Strategic Studies Group, commonly known as SSG, was an Australian software development company that primarily made strategy wargames. “Run5” was launched by SSG in January 1986.

Ian Trout had determined that print was the cheapest and most effective way to share new scenarios with the audiences for their games. In the editorial to the first edition Trout explains that print was much cheaper than creating disks which would “cost around $15 a pop”. As the son of a newspaper publishers and himself a bookshop proprietor Trout had a fondness for print publication and was interested in what SSG could achieve with its own magazine.

SSG was founded by strategy game enthusiasts Ian Trout and Roger Keating. Ian was proprietor of a military books store and Roger had had several of his games published by Strategic Simulations Inc. The game that launched the company was Reach for the Stars (1983). This games is credited for having “effectively launched the genre of 4-X space games - explore, expand, exploit, exterminate”. Its success was followed by a string of other, mostly historical military games published throughout the 1980s for Apple II, Atari, Commodore 64, and IBM PC series of computers. (some information for this entry dericed from Wikipedia)

description_for_label:
Strategic Studies Group, commonly known as SSG, was an Australian software development company that primarily made strategy wargames. “Run5” was launched by SSG in January 1986.

Ian Trout had determined that print was the cheapest and most effective way to share new scenarios with the audiences for their games. In the editorial to the first edition Trout explains that print was much cheaper than creating disks which would “cost around $15 a pop”. As the son of a newspaper publishers and himself a bookshop proprietor Trout had a fondness for print publication and was interested in what SSG could achieve with its own magazine.

SSG was founded by strategy game enthusiasts Ian Trout and Roger Keating. Ian was proprietor of a military books store and Roger had had several of his games published by Strategic Simulations Inc. The game that launched the company was Reach for the Stars (1983). This games is credited for having “effectively launched the genre of 4-X space games - explore, expand, exploit, exterminate”. Its success was followed by a string of other, mostly historical military games published throughout the 1980s for Apple II, Atari, Commodore 64, and IBM PC series of computers. (some information for this entry dericed from Wikipedia)
